awd_titl_txt: Standard Research Grant: A Comparative Study of Three Models of Innovation in Their Transnational Implementation
awd_abstract_narration:
General Audience Summary 

This project studies the practice turn in innovation policy by comparing the adoption of three best-practice models of innovation in four cities: Bangalore (India), Boston (USA), Cambridge (UK), Karlsruhe (Germany). The models in question are the MIT model, the Silicon Valley model, and the Public Engagement model. Each research site is regarded as a motor of innovation in its nation and each is a site where at least two of the models have been implemented. Informed by STS insights about the limits of standardizing, packaging, or universalizing social practices, the study asks what is at stake when social welfare is recast in terms of innovation policy and best practice transfer. The proposal uses qualitative STS research methods and focuses on the biotechnology and IT sectors for empirical analysis. The results of this study will have a direct impact on policy-practitioners (such as government officials, institutional managers, and consultants), who increasingly turn to plugin-type policy solutions but lack the analytic tools to theorize, evaluate, and coordinate these attempts. The study will explicate the assumptions and implications of using best practice transfer to promote social welfare and seek avenues to re-democratize technocratic approaches to innovation policy. It will sustain close interaction with the practitioners interviewed, and aims to amplify a critical public discourse on how the social welfare functions of the state are being redefined and redirected through innovation policy. Through a transnational network of researchers, it will extend to additional regions, thus generalizing the research beyond the four selected sites and three models. The project will provide education and training at the nexus of STS and innovation policy analysis.

Technical Summary 

This project explores how countries imagine their sociotechnical futures through the practice turn in innovation policy. This turn entails a three-fold shift in the use of innovation policy as an answer to basic socioeconomic challenges confronting 21st-century nations and a touchstone for governmental legitimacy, as a category that sees innovation as desirable and achievable through standardized practices; and as a benchmark activity preferably implemented through best-practice transfer. The study will illuminate the tacit assumptions, implementation experiences, institutional transformations, and broader social impacts of best practices transfer efforts. More specifically, it will address how each of the three best-practice models were systematized sufficiently to have global influence, how have policymakers interpreted these models and the underlying assumptions made in doing so, how the models are being locally implemented, how their performance have been assessed, how their circulation feed back into the redefinition of each, and the policy lessons of their circulation. The project lays the foundation for an innovation theory that accounts for the practice turn and best practice transfer as a de-facto mode of operation of policy actors. It will build upon and go beyond the dominant analytic frameworks of pipelines and systems of innovation, and it will extend prior STS efforts on responsible innovation and anticipatory governance by paying particular attention to the implications for democratic values such as equality, participation, and access to the fruits of innovation.

por.por_cntn:
Toward the end of the twentieth century, two visions of progress came to dominate policymakers’ imaginations around the world: first, that cities are sites where new ideas of human well-being and governance can be developed and implemented more effectively than at the level of nation states; and second, that California’s Silicon Valley is a powerful model for  connecting cities to a new global economy and enabling citizens to realize their individual ambitions for a better life. Silicon Valley served in this respect as a “sociotechnical imaginary,” a term defined in Science and Technology Studies (STS) as a collectively held, institutionally stabilized, and publicly performed vision of a good and desirable future that can be attained through the adoption and spread of technology. The good in Silicon Valley was understood to be innovation, a break from the old ways with their connotations of economic stagnation and social failure.

The project set out to compare the implementation of the Silicon Valley imaginary in four cities—Boston, Bangalore (India), Munich (Germany), and Cambridge (UK)—with a view to understanding better what makes a “traveling imaginary of innovation” attractive, and what parameters make it succeed or fail. The project sought to illuminate how each city had adapted best practices for innovation at three levels of institutional stabilization: the MIT model of channeling university-based research into development; the Silicon Valley model of promoting regional economic growth; and the public engagement model of producing democratic buy-in and political accountability for innovation.

As the project proceeded, it became clear that the lure of Silicon Valley extended well beyond the initial four-city study funded by NSF. One project achievement was to draw together researchers from a dozen cities and regions, each deeply committed to the idea of innovation through its local version of Silicon Valley: Bangalore, Barcelona, Berlin, Boston, Cambridge (UK), Copenhagen, Dakar, Munich, San Francisco, Santiago, Seoul, and Tel-Aviv. While policymakers in each location explicitly bought into the desirability of building their own Silicon Valley, research showed that the imagined ideal captured only some parts of the complex phenomenon they wished to emulate. An early finding that framed and shaped the case studies is that Silicon Valley was a panacea to policymakers precisely because it could be reimagined to cure vastly different economic, political, and social problems. In this respect, the traveling imaginary of Silicon Valley was less a remedy than a diagnostic revealing what each locality thought was missing in its pre-innovative state.

Comparison across the cases called into question—if not outright falsified—certain common presumptions accounting for Silicon Valley’s alleged success. To begin with, there was questionable success within the very region that birthed the phenomenon that became a model for the rest of the world. San Francisco, the city of permanent innovation, lost control of basic aspects of human well-being, such as transport, housing, and public safety. Munich, gifted with the infrastructure for becoming a powerful innovation hub, proved reluctant to disrupt existing socioeconomic arrangements. And Cambridge (UK) rejected the MIT model, opting instead for a more historically grounded approach to transforming its relationship to the British economy. Together, the case studies demonstrate the interpretive flexibility of the very notion of innovation. They exemplify the problems that arise when cities accept the imaginary without exploring baseline questions about innovation’s purposes, benefits, and burdens: for whom, to what end, at what cost?

An unexpected similarity across the cases became an entry point to deeper analysis. In almost every setting, the implementation of innovation projects included elements of the city’s material infrastructure: for example, a port in Tel Aviv, airports in Berlin and Dakar, roads in Bangalore and Barcelona. In developed as well as developing countries, the proposed expansion or modification of roads and airports sometimes aroused vehement opposition. Controversies around these projects revealed that many citizens saw “Silicon Valley” as shorthand for a form of global capitalism untethered from local forms of economic life, as well as from locally accepted rules of accountability. In short, being for or against Silicon Valley meant being for or against innovation that seemed disproportionately to favor imported forms of life over homegrown ones.

Innovation under the banner of Silicon Valley proved most successful where the goals were clear and inclusive and public assent was assured in advance; or where innovation was tightly coupled to civic problem-solving. Resistance and mismatch were most evident where policymakers adopted the imaginary without regard for existing social inequities and claims for social justice. Together, the studies underscore the crucial importance of continuity as opposed to disruption before the traveling imaginary of Silicon Valley can perform its magic of renewal. The study’s broader impacts include training a transnational network of students and researchers, demonstrating policy-relevant weaknesses in the Silicon Valley model of innovation, and outreach to NGOs and policy institutions throughout the project.
